title: Question 12

children: A 29-year-old man who works as a professional landscaper is evaluated for the skin lesions
Which of the following infections is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is sporotrichosis, which is caused by the fungus

lives in soil, moss, or other organic material frequently used in gardening and landscaping. The most common presentation of sporotrichosis is lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. The primary lesion is located at the site of inoculation (in this case, over the fourth metacarpophalangeal joint) and consists of an ulcerated nodule. Similar lesions occur proximally along the lymphatics (in this case, up the arm).
Sporotrichosis can also present as a plaque-like or verrucous-like lesion that typically appears on the face, as
on the tip of the nose of this child. Extracutaneous infection (osteoarticular, pulmonary, ocular, or disseminated) can occur in immunocompromised hosts.
